sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: The drawdot procedure is used to color the dot (pixel) at location (x, y) using the specified Color.
sections.mdown_content:
The **drawdot** procedure is used to color the dot (pixel) at 
location (*x*, *y*) using the specified *Color*.

sections.title: Example
code:
setscreen ("graphics")
        var x, y, c : int
        loop
            randint (x, 0, maxx)        % Random x
            randint (y, 0, maxy)        % Random y
            randint (c, 0, maxcolor)    % Random color
            drawdot (x, y, c)
        end loop
sections.raw_content: This program randomly draws dots with random colors. The maxx, maxy and maxcolor functions give the maximum x, y and color values.
sections.mdown_content:
This program randomly draws dots with random colors. The **maxx**, 
**maxy** and **maxcolor** functions give the maximum x, y and 
color values.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: The screen should be in a "graphics" mode. If the screen is not in a "graphics" mode, it will automatically be set to "graphics" mode. See setscreen for details.
sections.mdown_content:
The screen should be in a "*graphics*" mode. If the screen is 
not in a "*graphics*" mode,  it will automatically be set to 
"*graphics*" mode. See **setscreen** for details.

sections.title: Example
code:
var x, y : real
        var dx, dy : real
        var clr : int := 1
        x := Rand.Int (1, maxx - 1)
        y := Rand.Int (1, maxy - 1)
        dx := Rand.Real - 0.5
        dy := Rand.Real - 0.5
        loop
            drawdot (round (x), round (y), clr)
            clr := (clr + 1) mod maxcolor
            x := x + dx
            y := y + dy
            if x <= 0 or x >= maxx then
                dx := -dx
            end if
            if y <= 0 or y >= maxy then
                dy := -dy
            end if
        end loop
sections.raw_content: This program draws a line of dots that bounce off the “sides” of the screen. It also demonstrates that you can use real coordinates to store position (x, y), as long as you convert the coordinates to int values using round in the drawdot call.
sections.mdown_content:
This program draws a line of dots that bounce off the sides of the 
screen. It also demonstrates that you can use real coordinates to
store position (*x*, *y*), as long as you convert the 
coordinates to **int** values using **round** in the 
**drawdot** call.
